questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT of the chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. What is the person suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • The patient's history of working in a factory for a prolonged period, along with the HRCT chest findings of pleural thickening and fibrosis, points towards the diagnosis of Asbestosis, a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres commonly encountered in occupational settings.
  • Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the deposition of fibres in the lungs, triggering an inflammatory response that results in fibrosis and scarring of lung tissue, including the pleura.

Occupational Lung Disease

Associated Agents

Features

Diagnostic Tools

Preventive Measures

Asbestosis

(Option A)

Asbestos fibers

Characterised by progressive pulmonary fibrosis. Symptoms include dyspnea, non-productive cough, and chest pain. Often associated with pleural plaques and increased risk of mesothelioma and lung cancer.

HRCT, pulmonary function tests, occupational history

Use of protective gear, proper ventilation, asbestos abatement programs

Silicosis

(Option C ruled out)

Crystalline silica (quartz dust)

Presents with nodular pulmonary fibrosis, primarily in the upper lobes. Increased risk of TB and other respiratory infections. Chronic exposure can lead to progressive massive fibrosis.

Chest X-ray, HRCT, occupational history

Dust control measures, respirators, regular health check-ups

Coal Worker's Pneumoconiosis (CWP)

(Option B ruled out)

Coal dust

Also known as "black lung disease." Features similar to silicosis but usually affect the upper lungs with coal dust deposition and fibrosis, without the silicotic nodules.

Chest X-ray, HRCT, pulmonary function tests

Dust control, respiratory protective equipment, regular monitoring

Byssinosis

Cotton, flax, hemp dust

"Monday fever" describes worsening symptoms at the beginning of the workweek. Symptoms include chest tightness and wheezing, predominantly in textile workers.

Clinical evaluation, occupational history

Improved ventilation, dust suppression, health education

Berylliosis

(Option D ruled out)

Beryllium and its compounds

Acute or chronic lung disease caused by beryllium. Chronic form mimics sarcoidosis with systemic symptoms and granulomatous inflammation.

Lung biopsy, beryllium lymphocyte proliferation test (BeLPT), imaging

Limiting exposure, personal protective equipment, medical surveillance

Farmer's Lung

Moldy hay, crops, and compost dust

A type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by inhaling organic dust, presenting with malaise, cough, and breathlessness that may become chronic.

HRCT, pulmonary function tests, specific IgG testing for antigens

Respiratory protective equipment, proper storage of agricultural products

questions.text: A chronic smoker who worked in a cement factory for the past 20 years developed mesothelioma. This association is most likely due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • Mesothelioma is a malignant tumour of the pleura (and sometimes peritoneum or pericardium) that is strongly associated with asbestos exposure.

Asbestos fibres are commonly encountered in:

  • Shipbuilding
  • Construction
  • Cement manufacturing
  • Insulation materials

Chronic inhalation of asbestos fibres → fibres lodge in pleura → chronic inflammation & fibrosis → mutations → mesothelioma (and also increased risk of bronchogenic carcinoma, especially in smokers).

  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.

  • Asbestos-related lung carcinoma is markedly magnified by smoking. Thus, asbestos workers (particularly those who smoke) are at much higher risk of dying of lung carcinoma than mesothelioma.
  • Compared to other occupational lung diseases, which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.
  • Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer, accounting for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A patient working in a factory presented with lung fibrosis and thickening of pleura. Biopsy was done. Diagnosis from the histopathology picture is :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. 

  • Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by long-term exposure to asbestos fibers. Inhalation of these fibers leads to the formation of scar tissue and fibrosis in the lungs. It is characterized by the presence of asbestos bodies, which are asbestos fibers surrounded by iron-containing proteins, within lung tissue. The disease can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness. In the histopathology picture, the presence of lung fibrosis and thickening of the pleura is consistent with the diagnosis of asbestosis.

Incorrect Option: 

Option B. Silicosis:

  • Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust. It leads to the development of fibrous tissue in the lungs, similar to asbestosis. However, silicosis is characterized by the presence of silica particles within the lung tissue rather than asbestos bodies. Occupational exposure to industries such as mining, sandblasting, or stone cutting is commonly associated with silicosis.

Option C. Tuberculosis:

  • Tuberculosis (TB) is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also involve other organs. TB is characterized by the formation of granulomas, which are nodular inflammatory lesions, in the affected tissues. In the lungs, TB granulomas typically contain caseous necrosis, which appears as cheesy or crumbly material on histopathology. While TB can cause lung fibrosis in advanced cases, the thickening of the pleura mentioned in the question is not a typical finding of tuberculosis.

Option D. Mesothelioma:

  • Mesothelioma is a type of cancer that affects the mesothelium, the thin membrane that lines the chest cavity and covers the lungs. It is primarily caused by exposure to asbestos fibers. Histopathologically, mesothelioma is characterized by malignant cells forming a disorganized pattern within the mesothelium. While mesothelioma can cause lung fibrosis in some cases, thickening of the pleura is a more prominent feature associated with asbestosis rather than mesothelioma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a long history of dyspnea, chronic cough with sputum, and wheezing died of respiratory failure following a bout of lobar pneumonia. She was not a smoker or an alcoholic. The lung at autopsy is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most likely to cause the pathological changes shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and the gross specimen showing
  • emphysematous damage involving the enlargement of the entire acinus are consistent with panacinar emphysema.
  • This pattern of emphysema is most commonly associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the alpha-1 antitrypsin gene located on Chromosome 14.
  • Normal individuals have the PiMM genotype, while those with the disease have the PiZZ genotype.
  • This results in significantly reduced levels of functional alpha-1 antitrypsin protein.
  • Carriers possess the PiMZ genotype.
  • The condition primarily affects the lungs, leading to panacinar emphysema and the liver, causing cirrhosis due to abnormal protein accumulation.

 

Emphysema is classified according to its anatomic distribution within the lobule. Based on the segments of the respiratory units that are involved, emphysema is subdivided into four major types:

Features

Centriacinar (M/C)

Panacinar

Paraseptal

Irregular

Involves

Proximal acinus

Proximal & distal acini

Distal acinus

Irregular involvement

Site

Upper lobes, especially apical segments

Lower zones & anterior margins of the lung.

More severe at the base of the lung.

The upper half of the lungs (more severe).

 

Airspaces can form cyst-like structures.

Any part of the lung can be involved.

Aetiology

Smokers

Chronic bronchitis

α1-antitrypsin deficiency

Spontaneous pneumothorax

Depends on involvement, most found in autopsy

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a chronic cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain. He has a history of working in construction for several decades, where he was exposed to asbestos. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds over the lower lung fields. A chest X-ray shows bilateral, diffuse interstitial opacities. Pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest demonstrates "honeycombing" in the lung parenchyma. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • The patient’s prolonged asbestos exposure, chronic cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain suggest asbestosis, a form of interstitial lung disease (ILD).
  • Imaging findings, including bilateral interstitial opacities and honeycombing on HRCT, along with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, support the diagnosis of asbestos-induced pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.

 

 

  • Asbestos-related lung carcinoma is markedly magnified by smoking. Thus, asbestos workers (particularly those who smoke) are at much higher risk of dying of lung carcinoma than mesothelioma.
  • Compared to other occupational lung diseases, which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.
  • Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer, accounting for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: The most common lung finding in a COVID-19 infection is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse alveolar damage

Explanation:

  • The most common lung finding in COVID-19 infections is diffuse alveolar damage (DAD), characterized by injury to the alveolar epithelium and endothelium, leading to pulmonary oedema, inflammation and the formation of hyaline membranes.

 

 

COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2):

  • Transmission:
    • It likely originated from a seafood and animal market in Wuhan.
    • Initial animal-to-human transmission, followed by human-to-human spread.
  • Clinical features:
    • Range from mild flu-like symptoms to severe respiratory illness.
    • Severe cases often involve respiratory compromise and bilateral ground-glass opacities on chest imaging.
    • It is more severe in older adults and individuals with comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, COPD, heart failure).
  • Pathology: Histologic analysis of lung tissue shows diffuse alveolar damage and inflammation, primarily with mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with a cough, a low-grade fever, and hemoptysis. Investigations reveal a cavitary lesion on her right lung apex, which, on biopsy, reveals caseous necrosis. The underlying pathophysiology is:

choices.text: Sudden cut off of blood supply

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type-4 hypersensitivity reaction

Explanation:

  • The given scenario of cough, fever, hemoptysis, and a cavitary lesion with caseous necrosis at the right lung apex strongly suggests Pulmonary Tuberculosis, which involves a type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • CD4+ T cells activate macrophages, but Mycobacterium tuberculosis survives within them, causing granuloma formation with caseous necrosis, driven by a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction and resulting in tissue damage.

It is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can be classified into the following types:

1. Primary tuberculosis

  • It develops in a previously unexposed and, therefore, unsensitized person.
  • The primary organ involved is mostly the lungs.
  • Location:
    • Sub-pleural region.
    • Lower part of the upper lobe & upper part of the lower lobe.
  • Ghon’s focus: Grey-white area of inflammation with consolidation.
  • Ghon’s complex: Ghon’s focus + inflamed regional lymph nodes.
  • Histology: Granulomatous inflammatory reaction with both caseating and non-caseating tubercles.
  • Simon’s focus: Occult hematogenous dissemination to the apex of the lung.
  • Fate:
    • 95% of the cases are controlled by immunity, calcified, healed lesions and hilar lymph nodes (Ranke complex).
    • 5% of the cases are progressive (Progressive primary TB).
      • Resembles acute bacterial pneumonia.
      • Lymphohematogenous dissemination may cause tuberculous meningitis and/or miliary TB.

2. Secondary tuberculosis

  • It arises in a previously sensitised host.
  • It may follow shortly after primary tuberculosis, but more commonly, it appears months to years after the initial infection, usually when the host resistance is weakened.
  • The apical and posterior lobe segments are involved due to high O2 concentration (Puhl’s focus).
  • The infraclavicular lesion is called Assman’s focus.
  • Regional lymph node involvement is late.
  • Cavitation occurs readily with the erosion of the cavities into an airway.
  • Histology: Active lesions show coalescent tubercles with central caseation (Caseous necrosis).

3. Disseminated TB: Spread to other organs.

  • The images below show the caseous necrosis seen in TB.

 

Enzyme degradation (Option A) may be involved in the breakdown of tissue during infection. The primary mechanism of tissue damage in tuberculosis is the type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Fibrinoid deposition (Option C) refers to the accumulation of fibrin-like material in the walls of blood vessels. It is typically associated with conditions such as vasculitis.

Sudden cutoff of blood supply (Option D) occurs when the blood supply to a tissue is abruptly interrupted, leading to ischemia and subsequent tissue death. In the case of tuberculosis, the tissue damage is primarily caused by the immune response and the formation of granulomas.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time develops progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was the person most likely working in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Asbestos

Explanation:

The histopathological image shows ferruginous bodies, suggestive of Asbestosis, indicating the person likely worked in the asbestos industry.

  • It is a chronic lung condition caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres over a prolonged period.
  • These fibres accumulate in the lung tissue, leading to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring.
  • Symptoms: Includes shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness
  • The histopathological features seen in asbestosis include:
    • Interstitial fibrosis:
      • Asbestos fibres cause injury to the lung parenchyma, resulting in the deposition of collagen and fibrous tissue in the interstitium.
      • This fibrosis leads to thickening of the alveolar walls and restrictive lung function.
    • Ferruginous bodies:
      • Asbestos fibres can be recognized in the lung tissue as long, golden-brown, rod-shaped structures called ferruginous bodies.
      • These bodies are composed of asbestos fibre coated with iron and protein.

Silica (Option A) exposure is associated with a lung disease called silicosis. Histopathological features of silicosis include nodular lesions with silica particles, collagenous fibrosis, and concentric silicotic nodules featuring central collagen and a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages.

 

Coal dust (Option C) exposure is associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP). Histopathological features of CWP include the presence of coal macules (collections of carbon-laden macrophages) and coal nodules (fibrotic lesions with central cores of coal dust).

 

Cotton (Option D) exposure can lead to a lung disease known as byssinosis, also called brown lung disease. Histopathological findings in byssinosis include bronchiolitis and chronic bronchitis with peribronchiolar fibrosis.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopic image of lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-CoV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand in which of the following labelled layers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A

 

Explanation:

In the electron microscopic image of the lung tissue, the structure labelled "A" represents the endothelium, where SARS-CoV-2 infection would impact and cause expansion.

  • It is the virus causing COVID-19.
  • It leads to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
  • Mechanism: The virus can directly infect the endothelial cells that line the blood vessels in the lungs, disrupting the normal function and integrity of the endothelial cells, resulting in increased vascular permeability, inflammation, and the onset of pulmonary edema. (Option B)

 

Layer B (Option A) represents the basal lamina, which offers structural support to the epithelial cells and separates them from the underlying connective tissue. However, it is not the primary site of infection in SARS-CoV-2-related ARDS.

 

Layer D (Option C) represents epithelium that lines the airways and plays a key role in the respiratory system's defence mechanisms. However, it is not the primary target in SARS-CoV-2-related ARDS, where the main pathological changes occur in the endothelium.

questions.text: TTF-1 immunohistochemical marker is associated with which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lung adenocarcinoma:

  • TTF-1 is an immunohistochemical marker for lung adenocarcinoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: TTF-1 is not an immunohistochemical marker for these tumors.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with a persistent cough for 15 days. Upon examination, cervical lymphadenopathy is observed. A lymph node biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and caseating granulomas (central necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages and lymphocytes) in the biopsy strongly suggest Tuberculosis.

Type of Granuloma

Examples

Caseating Granuloma

Tuberculosis, Histoplasmosis, Coccidioidomycosis, Syphilis

Non-caseating Granuloma

Sarcoidosis, Crohn’s disease, Leprosy

Foreign Body Granuloma

Silicosis, Asbestos-related diseases, Foreign body reactions

Immune Granuloma

Wegener’s granulomatosis, Giant cell arteritis

Durck’s Granuloma

Cerebral malaria

Stellate Granuloma

Cat scratch disease

 

Causes of granuloma formation

Infectious causes

Non-infectious causes
  • TB (Caseating and non-caseating granuloma)
  • Leprosy
  • Syphilis
  • Malaria (Durck granuloma)
  • Cat-scratch disease and Lymphogranuloma venerum (Stellate granuloma)
  • Q fever (Doughnut granuloma/ Fibrin ring granuloma)
  • Sarcoidosis (Naked granuloma)
  • Giant cell arteritis
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic granuloma)
  • Berylliosis (Foreign body granuloma)

questions.text: Which malignancy is most commonly associated with asbestosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mesothelioma

Explanation:

  • Asbestosis, a pneumoconiosis caused by asbestos inhalation, is strongly associated with mesothelioma, a malignancy of the pleura or peritoneum.
  • Asbestos exposure also increases the risk of lung, laryngeal, ovarian, colon, and pleural cancers.
  • Smoking significantly amplifies the risk of asbestos-related lung carcinoma, making asbestos workers, especially smokers, more likely to die from lung cancer than mesothelioma.
  • Compared to other occupational lung diseases, which affect the upper lobes of the lungs, it commonly affects the lower lobes.
  • Adenocarcinoma (primary bronchogenic carcinoma) is the most common type of cancer, accounting for about 45%, followed by squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

 

Anthracosis (Option B), associated with bronchial arthrofibrosis (BAF), is a condition characterised by the black staining of the bronchial mucosa, which can obstruct the bronchial lumen. It typically manifests in elderly non-smokers, either male or female, with a chronic course of symptoms like dyspnea and/or cough. It occurs due to the accumulation of carbon, silica, and quartz particles in macrophages, mucosa, and submucosa, leading to anthracosis.

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option C) is the most common form of primary liver cancer. It typically develops in individuals with chronic liver diseases such as cirrhosis, which can be caused by chronic Hepatitis B or C infection. Other causes of cirrhosis include alcohol abuse, autoimmune diseases, chronic liver inflammation, and iron overload (hemochromatosis). HCC arises from long-term liver damage and scarring.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (Option D) is the most common type, accounting for approximately 90–95% of adult kidney cancers. It originates in the lining of the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs). Symptoms of RCC include blood in the urine, flank pain, abdominal mass, weight loss, fever, high blood pressure, night sweats, and malaise. When RCC metastasises, it commonly spreads to the lymph nodes, lungs, liver, adrenal glands, brain, or bones.

questions.text: A middle-aged man working in the sandblasting industry developed hemoptysis and a productive cough. A chest x-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Which of the following is associated with the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Silicosis

Explanation:

  • Silicosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust, which is commonly found in industries like sandblasting.
  • It is associated with a higher risk of developing tuberculosis due to the impairment of the immune response in the lung

Silicosis:

  • It is the most prevalent occupational lung disease in the world.
  • Cause: Inhalation of proinflammatory crystalline silicon dioxide (silica).
  • After decades of exposure, it usually presents as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis.
  • Occupations at risk:
    • Foundry work.
    • Sandblasting.
    • Hard rock mining.
    • Stone cutting.
    • Jewellers using chalk moulds.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Phagocytosis of inhaled silica crystals by macrophages activates the inflammasome and stimulates the release of inflammatory mediators, particularly IL-1 and IL-18.
    • This, in turn, recruits additional inflammatory cells and activates interstitial fibroblasts, leading to collagen deposition.
  • Forms of silica:
    • Amorphous.
    • Crystalline (quartz, cristobalite, and tridymite)- more fibrogenic.
  • Forms of silicosis:
    • Acute
      • Heavy exposure in closed spaces
      • Associated with Silico-tuberculosis and Secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis ( SPAP)
      • Can present within 2 years.
    • Chronic (simple):
      • Long-term (10-30 years)
      • less intense exposure.
      • Chronic Complicated: Chronic cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion.
  • Morphology:
    • Discrete nodules in hilar nodes and upper zones of lungs.
    • Hard collagenous scars.
    • Fibrotic lesions in nodes and pleura (pleural thickening).
    • Eggshell calcification (thin sheets of calcification in lymph nodes; calcium surrounding a zone lacking calcification).
    • Progressive massive fibrosis (1-10 cm).
    • Lung cancer (2-fold risk).
    • Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis infection.
    • Histological hallmark: Central collagen with a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages.
    • Polarized microscopy: Weakly birefringent silicate particles.
    • CT scan: Crazy pavement pattern and interstitial fibrosis.

 

Asbestosis (Option A) is caused by inhaling asbestos fibres, primarily leading to lung fibrosis and increasing the risk of lung cancer and mesothelioma. However, it is not directly linked to an increased risk of tuberculosis.

 

Anthracosis (Option C), or "coal miner’s lung," results from inhaling coal dust. It can cause chronic bronchitis or emphysema but does not have a direct association with tuberculosis.

 

Siderosis (Option D) is caused by inhaling iron oxide dust, typically seen in occupations like welding. It can lead to pulmonary fibrosis but does not significantly increase the risk of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A chronic smoker who worked in a cement factory for 20 years developed mesothelioma. It is due to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Asbestosis

Explanation:

  • Mesothelioma is primarily caused by exposure to asbestos fibres, which is a known risk factor for this type of cancer.
  • Long-term exposure to asbestos, especially in industries such as cement factories, is the most common occupational cause of mesothelioma.
  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common but is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

Mesothelioma

A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura, and it can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium, and tunica vaginalis

Etiology

Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening,
  • making the affected side rigid and immobile
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • A mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

CT scan shows Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)

Biopsy (Diagnosis can be confirmed)

  • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
  • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.

Specific markers for mesothelioma

  • Calretinin
  • Epithelial membrane antigen
  • Cytokeratin
  • Mesothelin

Prognosis

Poor - median survival of 9-21 months

Incorrect Options:

Silicosis (Option A) is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, commonly seen in industries such as mining and construction. While silica exposure can lead to lung fibrosis, it is not a direct cause of mesothelioma.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C), also known as black lung disease, results from the inhalation of coal dust. This condition affects the lungs but is not linked to mesothelioma.

Bagassosis (Option D) is caused by the inhalation of mouldy sugarcane dust and can lead to lung disease, but it is not associated with mesothelioma.

questions.text: A male patient is diagnosed with ARDS and is not responding to oxygen therapy. What is the role of IL-8 in ARDS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neutrophil recruitment:

  • Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a potent chemokine that plays a significant role in the inflammatory response in Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). Its primary function is to recruit neutrophils to the site of inflammation in the lungs. Once recruited, neutrophils release enzymes and reactive oxygen species that contribute to lung tissue damage, a hallmark of ARDS.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not influenced by IL-8.

questions.text: A patient presents with respiratory distress and is diagnosed with pan-acinar emphysema. Which deficiency is responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency leads to pan-acinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D do not cause pan-acinar emphysema.

questions.text: A patient presented with interstitial lung disease with an occupational history of working in a factory for 20 years and underwent a biopsy. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Asbestosis:

  • The given image shows dumbbell-shaped asbestos bodies, which, along with the history, suggests asbestosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Stanosis: Stanosis occurs due to tin/lead exposure.

Option B – Silicosis: Silicosis will show silicon particles on polarizing microscopy.

Option C – Byssinosis: Byssinosis occurs due to cotton dust/organic dust exposure, which is not mentioned in the patient’s history.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient on immunosuppressive therapy presents with a cough, fever, and pneumonia. A biopsy reveals the given findings. Which organism is responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CMV

Explanation:

  • The patient's presentation with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks and history of HIV with owl eye appearance in the image is suggestive of CMV (cytomegalovirus) pneumonia.

CMV (cytomegalovirus)

Class

Betaherpesvirinae subfamily of the Herpesviridae family.

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Host cells
  • Salivary gland
  • Kidney

Clinical features

Congenital infection

  • Most common intrauterine infection with congenital defects.
  • Common presentation:
    • Petechiae
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
  • Less common presentation:
    • Microcephaly
    • Cerebral calcifications
    • Intrauterine growth retardation
    • Prematurity
  • Other defects: Sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Perinatal infection

  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Occasionally, premature infants present with interstitial pneumonitis.

 

Immunocompromised

  • This is seen in AIDS, HIV, organ transplant patients and cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
  • Presentations in AIDS and HIV
    • CMV chorioretinitis
    • Progressive dementia,
    • Cranial nerve defects,
  • Presentations in Organ transplant
    • Bilateral interstitial pneumonia
    • Febrile leukopenia
    • Obliterative bronchiolitis
    • Graft atherosclerosis
    • Rejection of renal allografts.

 

Immunocompetent

  • Usually, it occurs following a blood transfusion.
  • It presents similar to infectious mononucleosis, but heterophile antibody tests would be negative.

Investigations

Peripheral smear: Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies.

 

 

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

 

Antigen detected: PP65

 

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies
  • CMV IgG antibodies
  • Against PP150 and PP65,
  • Against the PP52

 

PCR

  • Used in detecting CMV DNA
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (Drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

 

EBV (Epstein Barr virus) (Option A) primarily causes infectious mononucleosis, marked by fever, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes, and fatigue, and usually does not lead to pneumonia. Downey cells, or atypical lymphocytes, are large, vacuolated, and often display a ballerina skirt appearance.

 

Pox virus (Option C), like smallpox (eradicated) and molluscum contagiosum, causes skin lesions such as pustules or bumps. While they don't typically cause pneumonia, they can lead to systemic infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

Chickenpox (Option D), caused by varicella-zoster virus (VZV), leads to a rash of red spots and blisters. In immunocompromised patients, it can cause severe complications like varicella pneumonia, though less commonly than CMV or bacterial pneumonia, and may require antiviral treatment.

questions.text: Based on the biopsy image given below, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Adenocarcinoma:

  • The presence of glands in the given histopatholgy image indicates adenocarcinoma of the lung. In adenocarcinoma of the lung, neoplastic epithelial cells proliferate in a glandular pattern, forming well-differentiated tumors characterized by distinct glandular structures.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma: The absence of keratin pearls and desmosomes in the image indicates that it does not correspond to squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C - Small cell carcinoma: The image does not exhibit the salt and pepper appearance of chromatin or the Azzopardi Effect, features of small cell carcinoma.

Option D - Large cell carcinoma: Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated tumor characterized by the presence of large nuclei.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the provided histopathology of the enlarged cervical lymph node?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • The given histopathological image shows signs of chronic granulomatous inflammation, along with areas of caseous necrosis (seen as pink-colored areas) and Langerhans giant cells. All these findings are suggestive of Tuberculosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Sarcoidosis (Option A): Sarcoidosis typically presents with non-caseating granuloma or naked granuloma (lymphocytic collar absent). 


 

Histoplasmosis (Option C): Histoplasmosis shows the presence of small Histoplasma capsulatum yeasts.


 

Brucellosis (Option D): Brucellosis does not show caseous necrosis and Langerhans giant cells.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			A. Caplan’s syndrome
			
			
			1. Found first in coal worker
			
		
		
			
			B. Asbestosis
			
			
			2. Crazy pavement
			
		
		
			
			C. Mesothelioma
			
			
			3. Involves lower lobe
			
		
		
			
			D. Silicosis
			
			
			4. Pleural effusion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A-1, B-3, C-4, D-2

Explanation:

A. Caplan’s syndrome     
  • It is characterised by the formation of multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules, typically located in the lung periphery, in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis who have been exposed to inorganic dust.
  • It is primarily associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis but can also occur in other forms of pneumoconiosis.

B. Asbestosis
  • It primarily affects the lower lobes of the lungs and increases the risk of laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers, with lung cancer risk significantly heightened in smokers.
  • Asbestos-related lung carcinoma typically targets the lower lobes, unlike other occupational lung diseases that affect the upper lobes.

C. Mesothelioma
  • It is a rare cancer originating from mesothelial cells, most commonly affecting the pleura.
  • CT scan typically shows pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax.
  • It can also involve the peritoneum, pericardium, and tunica vaginalis.

D. Silicosis
  • It is the most prevalent occupational lung disease and is caused by inhaling proinflammatory crystalline silica.
  • After decades of exposure, it typically presents as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis.
  • The CT scan shows a "crazy pavement" pattern and interstitial fibrosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient arrives at the emergency room with complaints of respiratory discomfort. The patient has been experiencing shortness of breath, coughing, and chest pain for the past few weeks. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and there is no significant smoking history. Upon further investigation, a lung biopsy is performed, and microscopic examination reveals the presence of asteroid bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sarcoidosis:

  • The patient's presentation with shortness of breath, coughing, and chest pain for the past few weeks with lung biopsy performed and microscopic examination revealing the presence of asteroid bodies is suggestive of sarcoidosis.
  • Asteroid bodies are star-shaped inclusions seen within giant cells in granulomas and are a hallmark of sarcoidosis.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with skin lesions, respiratory symptoms, and enlarged lymph nodes. Skin lesions appear as raised, erythematous nodules, and a chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. A biopsy of the affected tissues is performed. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of granulomas without central necrosis. What is the most likely histological finding in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Non-caseating granuloma:.

  • The patient's presentation with raised erythematous nodules and a chest X-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis.
  • Sarcoidosis is associated with non-caseating granulomas with Schaumann bodies.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: An elderly male smoker presents with a chronic cough, significant weight loss, and fatigue. The serum calcium level is raised. A lung biopsy reveals large atypical cells with hyperchromasia. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Squamous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • An elderly male smoker with chronic cough, weight loss, fatigue, and elevated serum calcium likely has squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. This cancer is associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia due to PTHrP secretion. The biopsy showing large atypical cells with hyperchromasia supports this diagnosis.
  • Smoking significantly increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung as it has a strong association, resulting in chromosomal deletions involving tumour suppressor loci involving 3p,9p and 17p.

Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma is typically found in the central regions of the lungs (Not peripheral), often originating in the major bronchi near the hilum. It can cause symptoms by obstructing airways. Histopathologically, it is characterised by keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Location of lung carcinomas:

  • Central: Squamous cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma, and Bronchial carcinoids.
  • Peripheral: Adenocarcinoma and Large-cell carcinoma.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a patient with a history of smoking 24 packs, currently experiencing breathlessness and chest pain, and found to have a lung tumour with positive chromogranin staining?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation and positive staining for neuroendocrine markers such as Chromogranin and synaptophysin are highly suggestive of Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC) originating from neuroendocrine cells.

  • It is a highly malignant form of lung cancer associated with smoking and is known for its aggressive behaviour and early metastasis.
  • The genetic landscape of SCLC typically involves the inactivation of TP53 and RB genes.
  • L-MYC amplification is a common feature in some SCLC cases, contributing to the tumour's rapid growth and aggressive nature.

It usually arises from the pleura and presents with different symptoms, such as pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath.

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute respiratory infection:

  • Ciliocytophthoria refers to the presence of ciliated respiratory epithelial cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles containing inhaled particles, such as bacteria, viruses, or debris.
  • It is commonly observed in respiratory infections, particularly those affecting the lower respiratory tract.

Incorrect Options:

  • Ciliocytophthoria can be seen in options B, C, and D but is not specific to these conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been working in a factory for the past 20 years presents with breathlessness. HRCT of the of the chest shows pleural thickening and fibrosis. What is the person suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Asbestosis:

  • The patient's history of working in a factory for a prolonged period, along with the HRCT chest findings of pleural thickening and fibrosis, points towards the diagnosis of asbestosis.
  • Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, commonly encountered in occupational settings.
  • Prolonged exposure to asbestos can lead to the deposition of fibers in the lungs, triggering an inflammatory response that results in fibrosis and scarring of lung tissue, including the pleura.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D do not cause pleural thickening and fibrosis.

Option B - Coal worker pneumoconiosis:

  • Coal worker pneumoconiosis, also known as black lung disease, is caused by the inhalation of coal dust.
  • It typically presents with coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

Option C - Silicosis:

  • Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust.
  • It results in the formation of fibrotic nodules in the lungs.

Option D - Berylliosis:

  • Berylliosis is a lung disease caused by exposure to beryllium.
  • It primarily affects the lung parenchyma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old farmer was admitted with an acute onset of fever, cough, and dyspnea. A chest radiograph showed findings of pneumonia, for which he was treated with antibiotics and showed a good response. After 1 month, he again presented in a hypoxemic state with progressive dyspnea. The CT chest showed diffuse ground glass changes. Transbronchial biopsies showed numerous small granulomas and marked lymphocytosis. Which of the following is a causative agent for a given disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Thermoactinomyces sacchari

  • The patient's presentation with sudden fever, cough, and difficulty breathing and then improving and again deteriorating with diffuse ground glass changes on CT and multiple small granulomas on transbronchial biopsies suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis.
  • The most likely causative agent for the disease in this case is Thermoactinomyces sacchari.
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), classified as an interstitial lung disease, is characterized by a complex immunological reaction of the lung parenchyma in response to repetitive inhalation of a sensitized allergen.

Incorrect Options:

Aspergillus fumigatus (Option B): Causes a range of lung diseases including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in asthmatics, aspergilloma in patients with lung cavities, and invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in immunocompromised individuals.

Actinobacteria (Option C): causes pulmonary actinomycosis, a chronic lung infection that mimics TB or cancer.

Aspergillus flavus (Option D): causes invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients and may also contribute to aspergilloma or ABPA, similar to A. fumigatus, though it's less common.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mycoplasma pneumoniae:

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia.
  • It is a small bacterium that lacks a cell wall and is typically associated with mild respiratory symptoms such as cough, sore throat, and low-grade fever.
  • Atypical pneumonia refers to a milder form of pneumonia that often presents with non-specific symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not the most common cause of atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: The following cells seen in the lymph node are indicative of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Measles:

  • The presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells with large grapelike clusters of inclusion bodies is suggestive of measles infection.
  • The Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are multinucleated cells that contain viral inclusion bodies and are commonly seen in measles infections.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not associated with the presence of Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells.

questions.text: Identify the condition represented in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Miliary tuberculosis:

  • The image showing a lung specimen represents miliary tuberculosis.
  • Miliary tuberculosis is a form of tuberculosis characterized by the widespread dissemination of Mycobacterium tuberculosis throughout the body.
  • In this condition, the bacteria spread through the bloodstream and affect multiple organs, including the lungs.
  • The term "miliary" refers to the appearance of small millet seed-like lesions, which can be seen on imaging or in pathological specimens, giving the characteristic appearance seen in the image.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not present with the widespread millet seed-like lesions seen in the image.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male active smoker with a known case of bronchial asthma now presents with difficulty breathing, with the breath sounds being audible externally. Which of the following is not a feature you will expect to find in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in number of airway goblet cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fibroblastic foci:

  • Fibroblastic foci are not a characteristic feature of bronchial asthma.
  • Fibroblastic foci are commonly seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), a distinct disease characterized by progressive lung scarring and fibrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thickening of bronchial wall:

  • In bronchial asthma, chronic inflammation of the airways leads to hypertrophy and hyperplasia of smooth muscle cells, along with edema and infiltration of inflammatory cells.
  • This contributes to the thickening of the bronchial wall.

Option B - Increase in the number of airway goblet cells:

  • Goblet cells produce and secrete mucus in the respiratory tract.
  • In asthma, there is an increase in goblet cell hyperplasia, leading to excessive mucus production and airway obstruction.

Option D - Sub-basement membrane fibrosis:

  • Chronic inflammation in asthma can lead to remodelling of the airway wall, including thickening of the sub-basement membrane due to the deposition of collagen and other extracellular matrix components.
  • This contributes to airway narrowing.

questions.text: A 65-year-old HIV-positive man presented with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks. Imaging shows dense infiltration in the lower lobe, and the lung biopsy showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CMV pneumonia:

  • The patient's presentation with fever and breathlessness for 2 weeks and history of HIV with owl eye appearance in the image is suggestive of CMV pneumonia.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D do not have an owl eye appearance.
